paragraphs.text: When should voluntary euthanasia not be an option?
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: This week a court in Belgium announced that the convicted rapist and murderer Frank Van Den Bleeken would be put to death by a lethal injection, in spite of the fact that the death penalty is banned across Europe
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Van Den Bleeken's case was unusual
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: having previously been declared insane and not criminally responsible, he had himself asked to be euthanised on the grounds that he would rather die than spend the rest of his life in jail
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Today the Belgian justice minister announced that Van Den Bleeken would not be euthanised after all, amid reports that the prisoner had changed his mind
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Nonetheless
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the case provides a fascinating twist to the old debate about euthanasia
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Should Van Den Bleeken have been allowed to die?
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The moral defence of voluntary euthanasia is usually applied to people suffering from a terminal illness
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But Van Den Bleeken isn't terminally ill and isn't in physical pain
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Another traditional requirement is that the wish to die should be voluntary and competent
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But how can the choices of someone who has been declared insane be regarded as voluntary and competent?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The concern is that granting his request would make it a case of involuntary euthanasia
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: that is usually seen as morally unacceptable
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: If
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: there is an issue about Van Bleeken's sanity
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: that is because of his alleged inability to control his sexual impulses
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But it could be argued that this doesn't affect the validity of his request to be euthanised
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The implication is that while some of his decisions might be involuntary or incompetent, this doesn't apply to his choice of death over a lifetime behind bars
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Even so
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: should his request have been granted, given that he isn't terminally ill?
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: One argument for allowing voluntary euthanasia where terminal illness isn't an issue turns on the idea of wellbeing
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: people should be allowed to choose death where they would literally be better off dead or where their life literally isn't worth living
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Another argument turns on human autonomy
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: we should respect a person's free choices as long as they don't harm anyone else
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Someone who is not terminally ill could still satisfy these requirements
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Had Van Den Bleeken been allowed to die, critics may say it would have risked opening the floodgates for other similar cases
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Belgium has seen a dramatic rise in euthanasia since the practice was legalised in 2002 and permitted in cases of pain and psychological distress, as well as terminal illness
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: Some are opposed to voluntary euthanasia as a matter of principle
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The philosopher David Velleman argues that there isn't a fundamental right to choose between life and death, and that a person's rights don't expand when they become terminally ill or psychologically distressed
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: He is heavily influenced by 18th century philosopher Immanuel Kant
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: According to Kant, morality requires that we respect the dignity of persons, and the dignity of persons makes them intrinsically valuable
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: For Kant, a person's dignity can't be traded against their wellbeing or happiness
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the fact that a person believes that their life isn't worth living doesn't make it acceptable for them to be euthanised
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The Van Den Bleeken case puts pressure on these standard arguments for and against voluntary euthanasia
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Suppose that, contrary to Kant's view, voluntary euthanasia is morally permissible as long as the person asking to be euthanised would be genuinely better off dead
paragraphs.label: other

paragraphs.text: Relatives of Van Den Bleeken's victim may well argue that the fact(if it is a fact) that he would be better off dead is precisely a reason for not allowing him to be put to death
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: From this perspective, euthanasia looks like a way for him to circumvent his sentence
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Van Den Bleeken's victim was Christiane Remacle, a 19-year-old he raped and strangled in 1989
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Her sisters are reported to have said that Van Den Bleeken should be forced to languish in jail
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: their reaction brings out an ambivalence in how we think about the death penalty for murder
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Relatives of murder victims often demand the death penalty as the ultimate punishment
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the Van Den Bleeken case suggests that, at least from the standpoint of the perpetrator, the ultimate sanction may be life behind bars
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But the intrinsic value argument against voluntary euthanasia can also be hard to swallow, in this case
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Christiane Remacle's sisters might balk at the idea that a murderer's life is intrinsically valuable
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It's hard not to sympathise
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: there remain strong reasons for not allowing Van Den Bleeken to be euthanised regardless of whether his life is intrinsically valuable
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: As long as euthanasia is seen as a way for him to circumvent his sentence, respect for his victim and her family demands that he isn't given the option
paragraphs.label: assumption
